skill.name: changelog-automation
skill.description: Automate changelog generation from commits, PRs, and releases following Keep a Changelog format. Use when setting up release workflows, generating release notes, or standardizing commit conventions.
skill.summary: Automate changelog generation from commits, PRs, and releases following Keep a Changelog format. Use...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown templates and configuration examples. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no command execution. The skill provides patterns that users apply manually to their own projects.

content.user_title: Set up automated changelogs and releases
content.value_statement: Release notes and changelogs are often inconsistent and time consuming. This skill gives clear patterns to automate them with standard tools.
actual_capabilities: Provides a Keep a Changelog template with links and section examples
Defines Conventional Commit types mapping to changelog sections
Shows semantic versioning rules and when to bump major, minor, or patch
Includes configs for standard-version and semantic-release tools
Contains a GitHub Actions release workflow example with permissions
Provides release note templates for GitHub releases and internal use
limitations: Does not run tools or modify repositories directly
Requires external tools like semantic-release or git-cliff to be installed
Templates need project specific values and paths to be filled in
Assumes commit history follows Conventional Commits format

use_cases.title: Automate GitHub releases
use_cases.description: Generate consistent release notes and tags from commit history.

use_cases.title: Standardize commit messages
use_cases.description: Adopt Conventional Commits and enforce with commitlint configuration.

use_cases.title: Set up CI release pipeline
use_cases.description: Create a release workflow using semantic-release in GitHub Actions.

prompt_templates.title: Start a changelog
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Keep a Changelog file structure for my project with Unreleased and version sections.

prompt_templates.title: Adopt commit conventions
prompt_templates.prompt: Give me a Conventional Commits guide and commitlint config for our repository.

prompt_templates.title: Release automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a GitHub Actions workflow to run semantic-release on main and tag releases.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced templating
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a git-cliff configuration that groups commits by feature, fix, and refactor.

output_examples.input: Outline a release workflow with semantic-release and a changelog.
output: Define branch rules for main and prerelease branches.
Configure semantic-release plugins for changelog and git.
Add a CI workflow to install dependencies and run release.
Use Conventional Commits to drive versioning.

best_practices: Use Conventional Commits consistently across the team for automation.
Automate changelog generation in CI to avoid manual edits and errors.
Review release notes templates to match your audience and branding.
anti_patterns: Mixing unrelated changes into a single commit.
Editing generated changelogs by hand after automation runs.
Skipping version tags and relying on dates only for releases.

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The guidance is tool agnostic and works with all three AI coding platforms.

faq.question: What limits should I expect when using this skill?
faq.answer: The skill does not execute commands or read repositories. You must apply the patterns yourself.

faq.question: Can it integrate with GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: Yes. It includes a complete sample workflow for running semantic-release in CI.

faq.question: Does it access my data or credentials?
faq.answer: No. It is documentation only and does not access files, networks, or secrets.

faq.question: What if my releases fail in CI?
faq.answer: Check that tokens have correct permissions and commit messages follow the Conventional format.

faq.question: How does it compare to manual changelog edits?
faq.answer: It is more consistent, faster, and less error prone when commit messages are standardized.
